awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Diversification Dynamics of Multitrophic Interactions in Tropical Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
How is biodiversity generated and maintained? Much evidence suggests that parasites play an important role in both the origin and the maintenance of biological diversity. This project focuses on one of the most diverse groups of organisms on the planet: herbivorous insects, their parasites, and their microbes. The project targets three economically important groups of organisms: plants in the pumpkin/cucumber family, true fruit flies that attack these plants, and parasitic wasps that kill the flies. These wasps belong to a highly diverse and little studied group of species. Each wasp species can kill only one fly species; wasps attacking the "wrong" species of fly die. These bi-directional lethal interactions may be mediated by microbes (in wasps, flies, or both), by traits of flies' immune systems, or both. This project is designed to uncover the mechanisms (evolutionary, ecological, and immunological) affecting interactions that may help explain the diversity of life. Many species of true fruit flies are major agricultural pests; this project will greatly increase knowledge about factors contributing to their susceptibility to parasitoids. 

The project tests hypotheses that predict that: 1) defenses of parasites and their hosts affect diversification rates; 2) mechanisms of virulence differ among lineages, and 3) selection arising from predator-prey interactions can affect rates of species-formation. To discover and identify mechanisms of diversification, participants will generate and analyze molecular 1) high-resolution genetic data, multiple nuclear loci, and mtCOI haplotypes to delineate species, and resolve deeper phylogenetic relationships; 2) microsatellites and ddRAD-seq markers to discover and quantify fine-scale genetic diversity within and among populations; 3) phylogenies and field experiments to test hypotheses about mechanisms generating and controlling diversity on ancient, recent, and contemporary timescales. Undergraduate students from all participating colleges and universities will participate in the research.

por.por_cntn:
Genomes of plants and animals often contain clues about their histories, including who their closest living relatives are and where their ancestors may have lived. When coupled with ecological data, these genetic resources can be used to understand how complex biological interactions have evolved over time and space. We used genome-wide genetic data to study the histories of several species of specialist flies that are widely distributed across South America. These flies, in genus Blepharoneura, are notable for often having many different species living alongside one another on the same host plants. They are also known for being attacked by host-fly-specific species of parasitic wasp predators ? usually one wasp species per fly species ? but otherwise having highly effective immune systems that can kill the parasitic wasp predators of other flies. The result is that each fly species provides a small amount of protection to all of the other species that live on the same plant. Understanding how these flies came to co-occur with one another in the same plants, and how their highly specialized interactions with parasites have evolved are critical step towards determining how complex ecological interactions originate and change over time. We sequenced several thousand genomic loci from each of 732 flies representing 18 putative species of Blepharoneura fly and used this genetic data to study 1) the genetic relatedness among populations of the same species across South America, 2) the geographic and demographic histories of each fly species and 3) if, where, when, and under what circumstances each fly species has adopted different host plants. We found that many species have several genetically distinct populations and show signals of a historical split between Amazonian sites in Peru and Bolivia and sites in the Guiana Shield, possible corresponding to where rainforest refugia were found during the Pleistocene epoch. Shifts into new host plants appear to be rare within species, but host plants sometimes differ between species, suggesting that shifts could be correlated with speciation. These population genetic findings will now be considered alongside fly-wasp interaction data collected over the course of this funding period by the other PIs on this collaborative grant. The integrated datasets should reveal new and exciting conclusions about the evolution of interactions between plants, insects, and predators across time and space.

This project resulted in the training of an undergraduate student, three graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar, all women and all (except for one of the graduate students) first generation college students. The undergraduate student presented her work at a regional population genetics conference and has since gone on to graduate school in genetic counseling. Two of the three MS students have already graduated, and one is now a PhD student at the University of Chicago, while the other is a professional science writing editor here in Iowa City. The postdoctoral scholar successfully applied for faculty positions and now holds the rank of Assistant Professor at Ohio State University. The project has also led to the development of new teaching resources for training students in ?third-generation? sequencing platforms. These resources are currently in use both at the University of Iowa and at Ohio State University.
